name: Get Help
section_name: Get help with your own family history work.
summary: Although The Family History Guide has a wealth of resources and tasks to work on, there are times when you need some personal assistance with challenges in your family history. This goal points you in the right directions.

choices.name: Explore the Ancestry Support Center.

content.text:
1. In the top menu, click Help and select Support Center.
  2. To search for an article, type a keyword in the Search bar and click Search.
  3. To find a Help article by topic, click one of the topic buttons.
  4. You can also select an article from the "Trending Articles" box.

resources.description: Learn more about the Support Center in this article.

choices.name: Get help for your own research tasks.

hidden.content:
• Online researchers can be used to help with your own genealogy.
  • Volunteers are located all over the world that are willing to look up records and make information accessible to you, without traveling to that area.

• * Good: Reach out to one or more researchers to get help with one of your family lines.
  • * Same as above; also get help from a lookup volunteer and study crowd-sourcing tips for your genealogy.

content.text:
1. Know how to ask the right questions to get the help you need.

    ☆ AJC—How to Get Your Genealogy Questions Answered - 2016

  2. Find volunteer researchers who can help you on the Random Acts of Genealogical Kindness site.
  3. Get help searching records from lookup volunteers noted on the Genlookups site.
  4. Find help translating genealogical documents with the Genealogy Translation Facebook group.
  5. Explore the FamilyTreeCircles site for help with crowd-sourcing your family history.

choices.name: (Optional) Explore the resources at a family history center.

content.text:
1. Visit a local family history center and talk with a volunteer. These services are free to all. To find a list of nearby family history centers, click here. To find a family history center anywhere in the world, click here.
  2. Use the free Premium website offerings at a family history center. These include full access to Ancestry, Findmypast.com, Ancestry.com and others. See the full list of premium sites available at each family history center.
  3. Explore Ancestry questions in the ☆Genealogy Stack Exchange.

name: Message Boards
summary: Ancestry Message Boards help you connect with other Ancestry members to post questions about a wide variety of topics and get helpful feedback.

choices.name: Search for content and message board types.

content.text:
1. In the top menu, click Help and select Message Boards.
  2. To search for content in the Message Boards, type names or keywords in the first box and click Search. You can also click the Surnames button to limit the search to surname boards.
  3. To use advanced search features,
    a) Click "Advanced Search";
    b) Fill in any of the search fields as needed;
    c) Choose a message classification from the drop-down list;
    d) Choose a timeframe in the "Posted Within" drop-down list; and
    e) Click Search.
  4. To search for a specific type of message board, type a surname or topic in the second box and click Go.
  5. To search for surnames alphabetically, click a letter in the list and continue to refine the search until you see the surnames you want.
  6. Watch these videos for tips on using message boards in Ancestry.

    ☆ AAC—How to Find Message Boards—2:17
    ☆ AAC—How to Write a Message Board Query—1:28

choices.name: Explore categories and read messages.

content.text:
1. To find Message Board threads in localities,
    a) In the Categories section, click a category (to see more, click the "More Localities Categories" link);
    b) If another list of categories appears (folders), open the category you want;
    c) Click the Message Board title (message icon); and
    d) Click a title of interest to read the message thread.
  2. To find message threads in topics,
    a) Click a category (to see more, click the "More Topics Categories" link); and
    b) follow the rest of the step above.
  3. Click a thread title to read the message. If you want to open all the messages, click the "Change to Flat View" link.
  4. Click a message title in the list to read it. The message is marked as read in the list (the orange dot is removed).
  5. You can click the author's name to see his or her profile, or click "View posts" to see all messages the author has contributed.
  6. If you want to open all the messages, click the "Change to Flat View" link. In Flat View, you can select the message order as "Oldest First" or "Newest First".
  7. To see more messages per page, select an amount in the "per page" drop-down list (bottom of the page).
  8. To go to another page of messages (if available), click the left or right arrow (bottom of the page).
  9. To read the next or previous message thread, click "Next Thread" or "Prev Thread".
  10. To navigate back to previous Message Board screens, you can click any of the links shown in the path (top of the window).

choices.name: Respond to messages or print them.

content.text:
1. In an open message, click the Reply icon (left arrow).
  2. Type the message reply. You'll be notified when someone responds to your message, unless you clear the alert checkbox.
  3. If desired, type one or more surnames that appeared in the message.
  4. Select a classification type from the drop-down list.
  5. To learn more about creating effective message posts, click the "What is this" link.
  6. To include an attachment, click Choose File and navigate to the file.
  7. To preview your post, click "Preview". When you're ready, click Post to send the message.
  8. To print a post, click the printer icon (lower-right corner of the post) and follow the prompts.

choices.name: Create your own message thread.

content.text:
1. In an open thread or message, click Begin New Thread.
  2. Fill in the Subject line and other fields as explained in Choice C above.
  3. To learn more about creating effective message posts, click the "Board FAQ" link (top of the page).
  4. To preview your post, click "Preview". When you're ready, click Post to send the message.

name: Member Connect and Collaboration
section_name: Use Member Connect and other collaboration tools.
summary: The Member Connect feature helps you stay in touch with other Ancestry members who are researching common ancestors.

choices.name: Explore Member Connect.

content.text:
1. In the Profile for an ancestor, click Tools and select Member connect.
  2. Follow the steps in this article to see a list of people who likely have the same person in their trees, to save a tree on the list, to compare your tree to theirs, or to remove a connection.
  3. For more information on using Member Connect, watch this video.

    ☆ Member Connect on Ancestry—7:17 - 2021

choices.name: Use other collaboration tools.

content.text:
1. To search other Ancestry member trees that are public,
    a) In the Collaborate panel, click the "Public Member Trees" link;
    b) Fill in the search fields (see Project 4, Goals 4-6 for search tips);
    and c) Click Search. Note : Data in other trees is not guaranteed to be complete or accurate, but it may be helpful in your research.
  2. To use the Member Search feature to find an Ancestry Community member by name,
    a) In the Collaborate panel, click the "Member Directory" link;
    b) Click the "Member Search" link;
    c) Type a name or user name in the box and select it;
    d) Click Message and fill in the fields; and
    e) Click Send.
  3. To use Member Search to find an Ancestry Community member by research interest,
    a) In the Member Search page, click the "Find a specific member" link and select "Find members by research interest";
    b) Type a surname of interest;
    c) Type a location and select it from the list;
    d) Type a year of interest; and
    e) Click the magnifying glass icon. You can then click a username to contact that person, or click the person's family tree link if available.

name: Genealogy Societies
section_name: Get involved with genealogical societies for information and support.

choices.name: Learn about genealogical societies.

hidden.content:
• Genealogical societies often know and have more information about a specific locality than is available online or in other resources.
  • Genealogical magazines help you stay up to date on news and can provide inspiration or examples that help you solve challenges in your own tree.

• Camaraderie and breaking brick walls
  • Local experts
  • Speakers and presentations
  • Special topics sessions
  • Communications to members and the community
  • Become a speaker
  • Keeping up to date
  • Support

• * Good: Study the resources for genealogical societies above, and then join one of them. Also find at least one online genealogy magazine to follow.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, with two genealogy societies and three online genealogy magazines.

content.text:
1. Read these articles for an overview of genealogical societies.

    ☆ GC—Using Historical and Genealogical Societies
    ☆ AR—Genealogy Societies: They Do Your Genealogy Good

  2. Read this article from the FamilySearch Wiki about U.S. genealogical societies.

    ☆ United States Societies

  3. This article suggests three genealogical societies every genealogist should join.

    ☆ 3 Genealogy Societies Every Serious Genealogist Should Join

  4. Here are eight reasons for joining a genealogical society.

    ☆ 8 Reasons to Join a Genealogical Society—5:23  
    • Camaraderie and breaking brick walls
    • Local experts
    • Speakers and presentations
    • Special topics sessions
    • Communications to members and the community
    • Become a speaker
    • Keeping up to date
    • Support




  5. Learn about popular online genealogy magazines and what they offer.

    ☆ GI—Top 10 Popular Online Genealogy Magazines

choices.name: Find U.S. and international genealogical societies.

content.text:
1. Explore the NGS (National Genealogical Society) website for U.S. genealogy societies.
  2. See an international list of genealogy societies on the Cyndi's List site.
  3. Refer to the "Get Help" goals in most of the Country pages for information about genealogy societies and social media groups for specific countries.
  4. See Project 4: Discover, Goal 1, Choice D for tips on writing to individuals and organizations for genealogy help.

name: Collaboration
section_name: Collaborate with others doing family history work. Vault

choices.name: Share your family history efforts.

hidden.content:
• What is a blog
  • Blogger vs. Wordpress
  • Your own domain name
  • What do you want to accomplish?
  • Decide on a topic and theme
  • A blog is a form of social networking
  • Some popular genealogy blogs
  • What about social networking?
  • Genealogical benefits of social networking
  • What about reading all those blogs?

• * Good: Use one of the methods above to share your family history with others.
  • * Proficient: Use several of the methods above to share your family history with others.

content.text:
Remember to get permission from living individuals if you share their information.

  1. Watch these videos for ideas on sharing your family history information with others.

    ☆ AC—Quick Ways to Share Family History—15:31 - 2012


    ☆ FS—Share with Others—3:08 - 2011

  2. Here are some tips on collaborating with other researchers.

    ☆ FL—Genealogy Research in the 21st Century Part 3: Collaboration and Personal Communication - 2020

  3. See also www.Family.me for building a collaborative family tree.
  4. Join the 52 Ancestors in 52 Weeks Challenge - 2019. You'll receive weekly prompts on ways you can share your family history findings with others.
  5. Here are some additional tips on sharing your family history.

    ☆ RT—Sharing Family History in Fun and Modern Ways - 2019
    ☆ LDS—Sharing Your Family History - 2018

  6. Social Media: Learn how blogging and social networking can help you collaborate on family history.

    ☆ BYU—Blogging and Social Networking for Genealogists—62:53 - 2017  
    • What is a blog
    • Blogger vs. Wordpress
    • Your own domain name
    • What do you want to accomplish?
    • Decide on a topic and theme
    • A blog is a form of social networking
    • Some popular genealogy blogs
    • What about social networking?
    • Genealogical benefits of social networking
    • What about reading all those blogs?



    ☆ How to Network with Family Members Using Social Media for Genealogy Research - 2016

  7. Use social media to share your family history efforts.

    ☆ AAC—Cousin Bait: Making Social Media Work for You—47:19

  8. Learn how to use social media for your family history research queries.

    ☆ BYU—Leveraging Social Networking Resources for Genealogical Queries—60:05 - 2022

choices.name: Work with others on family history.

hidden.content: • Working with others requires planning. Make sure to divide up tasks and keep up communication to avoid duplicate efforts.

• Check your tree settings
  • Check your profile
  • Card catalog
  • Find an online community

• Have your tree noticed online
  • Best places to connect with relatives and locations
  • Connect and collaborate with groups
  • Handling snowballing information
  • Future and conclusion

• Family history on phones
  • Descendants with tasks
  • Recommended tasks
  • Using record hints to get death dates
  • Maiden names
  • Full set of microtasks
  • Recap

• * Good: Identify one or two collaborators for your family history work. Contact them and get started with your collaborative research.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, with at least 5 collaborators.

content.text:
1. Get family members or friends involved in collecting memories (photos, documents, stories, etc.) to be uploaded to FamilySearch.
  2. Divide up family lines for research, to avoid duplication of effort.
  3. Keep each other informed about progress achieved as well as roadblocks that remain.

resources.description: Study these resources for additional ideas about working with others on family history.
Learn how you can collaborate with other generations on your research.

links.text: MH—How to Collaborate with Other Generations on Your Genealogical Research - 2019

resources.description: Here are some tips on involving others who may be reluctant to participate in family history.

links.text: AF—Drawing Those Hesitant Relatives into Your Family Tree Research - 2016
AF—How I Got My Family Involved In Genealogy Research

resources.description: Locations: Learn how to create an online community for a town you are researching.

links.text: RT—Creating an Successful Online Community for the Town You're Researching—20:08 - 2022

resources.description: Microtasks: Learn how to use "microtasks" to spread family history assignments.

links.text: BYU—Using Microtasks to Involve Everyone in Family History Research—27:38 - 2018

resources.description: Descendancy/Cousins: Read this article to learn how you to find distant cousins who may want to help you with your research.

links.text: GT—Collecting Cousins--Turning Over Rocks with a Well-Placed Query

resources.description: Mailing Lists: Learn how to use mailing lists on Ancestry to keep in touch with others who are researching similar surnames or topics.
Family Tree: Learn how to collaborate effectively with others who are working in the FamilySearch Family Tree.

links.text: BYU—Tips for Working Collaboratively on the FamilySearch Family Tree—60:37 - 2022

resources.description: Other Trees: Learn how to share photos and documents that pertain to people in other family trees.

links.text: RT—Putting Things In Their Place: Paying it forward in the digital age—23:42 - 2022

choices.name: Organize or participate in family gatherings that promote family history.

hidden.content: • Family history gatherings are opportunities to learn more about family members while also sharing genealogical information and planning how to distribute future research that needs to be done.

• * Good: Participate in the planning for a family history reunion.
  • * Proficient: Lead the planning for a family history reunion.

content.text:
1. Plan for successful family history reunions.

    ☆ GC—Tips for the Size and Shape of Your Reunion
    ☆ GC—Sharing Family History at the Reunion

  2. Involve and include more family members in family history activities.

    ☆ GC—What Should We Do at the Reunion?

  3. Here are some tips for including family history in your next reunion.

    ☆ FS: 3 Tips for Family History at Your Next Reunion - 2016

choices.name: Join an online user group or forum for a genealogy website.

hidden.content:
• What is an online query?
  • Queries are organized ...
  • Surnames
  • Mailing lists
  • Message boards
  • GenForum

content.text:
Here are some noted user groups and online communities for genealogy and family history:

  1. Use the Member Connect feature in Ancestry to stay in touch with other Ancestry members who are researching common ancestors. For details on Member Connect, see this page.
  2. For tips on writing queries to online help groups, read this article.

    ☆ OT—Good Query vs. Bad Query - 2017

  3. Explore the GenForum Message Board for answers to questions.
  4. On Facebook, contact the RootsMagic user group or the Legacy Family Tree user group for answers to questions on their respective software versions.
  5. Learn how to use mailing lists and message boards to help solve your research brick walls.

    ☆ RT—Crowdsourcing Your Brick Walls, Part 1—16:50 - 2021  
    • What is an online query?
    • Queries are organized ...
    • Surnames
    • Mailing lists
    • Message boards
    • GenForum

choices.name: Create or join a family association.

hidden.content: • Family associations are an additional source of information that build connections and are a way of sharing information with the people it is most relevant to.

content.text:
1. Read the article for an introduction to family associations.

    ☆ GC—Family Associations 101

  2. Learn about effective ways to run a family association.

    ☆ GC—Running a Family Association

  3. Create a Facebook group for your family.

    ☆ FS—Facebook and Family History - 2016

  4. Publish a periodical for your family association.

    ☆ GC—Publishing a One-Family Periodical

choices.name: Decide on a Table of Contents for the history.

hidden.content:
• A Table of Contents should focus on topics, people, or places.
  • It should be organized and labelled appropriately, since it is the first thing people will look at when searching for information.
• * Proficient: Draft an effective Table of Contents for a family history book.

content.text:
Be sure to spend adequate time planning, writing, and revising the Table of Contents, as it's the foundation for organizing the work that will be published.

  1. Select the ancestors who will be highlighted in the history.
  2. Select the topics to be included, for each ancestor and in general.

    ☆ GC—Choose Your Family Book's Focus
    ☆ GC—Creating a Family History Book

choices.name: Write the history.

hidden.content:
• Incorporate information and stories in such a way that makes your family history compelling to read while also giving relevant information.
  • Read and watch articles about writing a family history to figure out the approach you would like to take.

• What is protected by copyright?
  • Who owns the copyright?
  • When does copyright protection expire
  • How can I use copyrighted works safely?
  • Why do I need to worry about copyright?
  • Common copyright myths
  • Additional resources

• * Good: Write several chapters of a family history book or publication.
  • * Proficient: Complete, or nearly complete, the first draft of a family history book or publication.

content.text:
1. Steps: Here are 10 steps to writing an effective family history.

    ☆ TH—10 Steps to Writing Your Family History - 2019
    ☆ RT—Writing and Publishing a Family History: 10 Steps—58:48 - 2019

  2. Watch this video for steps to writing and publishing a family history.

    ☆ AA—10 Steps to Publishing a Family History—62:00

  3. Tips: Watch this video for tips on writing content for your family history project.

    ☆ BYU—Writing a Family History—24:43

  4. Read this article for additional tips on writing content for your family history project.

    ☆ Secret to Writing a Compelling Family History

  5. Copyright: Understand the basic copyright issues for genealogists.

    ☆ AA—Copyright Essentials for Genealogists—50:39 - 2016   
    • What is protected by copyright?
    • Who owns the copyright?
    • When does copyright protection expire
    • How can I use copyrighted works safely?
    • Why do I need to worry about copyright?
    • Common copyright myths
    • Additional resources



    ☆ AR—What You Should Know About Copyright And Genealogy - 2012

choices.name: (Optional) Publish the history.

content.text:
1. Here are some ideas for publishing your family history book.

    ☆ TH—Publishing Your Family History Book - 2019

  2. Here are some helpful tips for publishing a family history.

    ☆ AR: Publish Your Family History Without Being Overwhelmed - 2013
    ☆ AA: Writing & Publishing Your Family History

choices.name: (Optional) Build a family history website to share information.

content.text:
1. Watch these videos to learn how to build a family history website using the Weebly.com platform.

    ☆ Part One—11:23 - 2012


    ☆ Part Two—14:12 - 2012


    ☆ Part Three—32:21 - 2012

name: Ancestry World Archives
section_name: (Optional) Participate in the Ancestry World Archives Project, or other indexing projects.
summary: Ancestry has a worldwide archiving project that provides indexes for record collections.

choices.name: Get started with the World Archives Project.

content.text:
1. Read the Introduction to the World Archives project.

    ☆ AC—Introduction to World Archives

  2. Download the keying tool for PC or for Mac.

choices.name: Do record keying for projects.

content.text:
1. Watch the keying videos from Ancestry.
  2. Use other resources available on the Ancestry Support page for World Archives.

choices.name: Participate in the Canadian Census Indexing Project.

content.text: 1. See the Automated Genealogy web page for details and instructions.
